name: Cyclohexane

energies.comment: Saturated 6-membered ring in chair conformation. Shows +7.2 ± 1 kJ/mol violation - MINIMAL, confirming chair conformation has negligible strain as expected. Tests whether cycles amplify correlation WITHOUT π-conjugation. Answer: Geometric cycles alone show WEAK amplification compared to electronic conjugation (benzene: +148 kJ/mol is 20× larger). Calculated from NIST: ΔHf = -123.1 ± 0.79 kJ/mol → BDE = (6×716.68 + 12×218.0) - (-123.1) = 7039 kJ/mol. CORRECTED from previous value (7055, +23 kJ/mol) which overestimated by 220% (+16 kJ/mol error).
energies.source: Prosen et al., J. Res. NBS 1946, 37:51-56; NIST Chemistry WebBook
energies.confidence_note: NIST-verified experimental value. Minimal violation confirms geometric cycles alone provide weak amplification. Electronic conjugation is necessary for strong feedback effects.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 6(C-C) + 12(C-H) = 6(346) + 12(413) = 7032 kJ/mol

notes: Cyclohexane is saturated (no π-electrons, no conjugation)
Chair conformation minimizes angle and torsional strain
Still forms a CYCLE - geometric constraints create correlation
NIST-verified violation: +7.2 ± 1 kJ/mol - MINIMAL as expected for chair conformation
Tests: Can geometric cycles alone amplify additivity violations? Answer: WEAKLY
Compare to benzene (+148, electronic + geometric) - 20× stronger!
Compare to hexatriene (+74, acyclic electronic) - 10× stronger!
Compare to butadiene (+38, acyclic electronic) - 5× stronger!
Conclusion: π-conjugation is NECESSARY for strong feedback amplification
Geometric cycles alone show minimal effect (+7 kJ/mol)
This distinguishes geometric vs electronic contributions clearly
